threads.com:
/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

threads.com:
I just finished organizing my reading list and downloading all the files.
>1. Mythology - Edith Hamilton
>2. A Brief History of Ancient Greece: Politics, Society, and Culture
>3. Homer - Iliad and Odyssey
>4. Hesiod - Theogony + Works and Days
>5. Aesop Fables
>6. Comedy : Menander and Aristophanes (basically all works)
>7. Tragedy : Aeschylus + Sophocles + Euripides (basically all works)

So, what you guys think of my list? I planned to read all of them during the course of a year, but I won't rush it without understanding the text, if it takes longer it takes longer. I left philosophy and the histories out because right now I want to focus on literature and will focus on these topics in a few years. Maybe even start Plato and Aristotle after this list.
I didn't specify the translation because I researched the best ones in my native language.

threads.com:
Do you guys keep a Journal? I started over a year ago and so far have filled three books each containing 193 pages. I started doing it as a way to reflect on my day and hash out projects I had on the go instead of talking the ear off of my coworkers in the parks service. I have a tendency to talk alot about things I have going on, often repeating myself in the process so this is a harmless way of doing that without occupying the time of those around me.
I don't think its the fix all cure that alot of mental health gurus talk about but its very nice to have, I do atleast one page a day, everyday. I track the weather and the temperature outside too.
I was curious if any of you guys keep one and if so what for? I know a few people who have Gardening and Reading Journals where they log basic info like the weather, quality of the plants, and the amount of pages theyve read.
Its a pretty nice exercise in habit.

threads.sub: What makes your favorite (English language) poets special?
threads.com:
It doesn't have to be elaborate, just what stand out about them to you.

I've only just started reading poetry, using Bloom's anthology. The poets that have really stood out so far have been Donne, Shakespeare, Wordsworth, Shelley and Whitman. They all seem to have a clarity to their writing that appeals to a new poetry reader like myself, and English poetry would be incomplete if Song of Myself never came into existence.

C. Rossetti, Housman and Frost have felt like easier, comfy poets.
Blake can be cool sometimes although he's often too 'out there'. Tennyson's Ulysses is superb. I wish I liked Dickinson more. Her style is quite compelling, but most of her content just doesn't seem to click.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21311482
i can't speak for others, but for me, the appeal of donne is the solving of the riddle of his words. much like shakespeare, once my mind has adjusted to his tongue, it loses its veneer and i must go and look at other things a while and forget before i can enjoy it again.
other poets like marlowe or pope i enjoy but for a more casual delight. blake, oh blake, that mad gnostic schizophrenic gentleman. as someone quite familiar with that particular flavor of mind, he is the best example of the depth of their internal hierarchies. nowhere else can it be so clear to one that there are whole kingdoms built and burned just to explain the visions that churn within their boiling brains. poor bloom. i saw him the day he died, before i heard of his death, i saw him flash a look at me through the car door mirror on my way to wal-mart with my mother. that poor gnostic monster whose heart was born for lance of king that never surfaced (for i was hidden and am hidden still), he razed and blasted all villages he could find, and god bless and forgive his dark soul.

the best part of any poet for me, is the plangency of his voice. if his song burst through the page, if i can hear that, if it overwhelms me, if i lose myself to that song, then i don't need nothin else.

I think you're running too quickly into the classic socialist critique. More than anything, Ilyich's mundanity is a reflection the prototypical reader: Tolstoy is saying, "This is YOU. This is YOUR fate."
The novella is less a critique of bourgeois materialism, and more of a contrast between the failures of conventional society to address the inevitability of death and the meaning of life, with the relative success of pastoralism and childlike innocence, as seen in Gerasim and Ilyich's son respectively. If I recall correctly, one of Ilyich's last thoughts was a question of how he lost his own innocence and let attrition wear him down.

threads.com: what books have some of the best action/fight scenes? what is your best advice for writing fight scenes? pls provide some resources, I’m trying to research and write something GOOD

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Action should be passed over as quickly as possible in written storytelling, as it is innately uninteresting.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21311663
your mum is innately uninteresting

last_replies.name: Anonymouṡ
last_replies.com:
>>21311478
You don't write better fight scenes by becoming a better fight-scene-writer; you write better fight scenes by becoming a better writer.

Getting better at writing any sort of scene will make you a better writer of fight scenes.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21311478
The Broken Sword by Poul Anderson

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Don't gloss over it, but keep it snappy. What matters less is describing each individual movement or attack - noone focuses this hard or perceives this quickly in an actual fight, and thus it bogs down the tone and action when we spend inordinate amounts of time reading about things that occur in a fraction of a second.
Just focus on retaining the feeling of snappiness, brutality and violence. If you're willing to get real jazzy with it, try to also apply your character's personalities to how they fight. A ruthless, unyielding and unflinching stoic will power through his enemies with impossibly powerful techniques, used pragmatically and sparingly. A goofier character might fight in a more roundabout manner, relying on trickery and diversions. A physically strong character might prefer to overwhelm their opponents with raw strength alone and stay unarmed, while a weaker character might be more prone to panicking and improvising weapons from the scenery.
Finally, be sure to consider how the action impacts your characters. Violence is inherently a traumatic experience, but people can react to it wildly differently, especially if they are more used to it than others.
Keep all this in mind and you'll be far ahead of the norm when it comes to writing action. Most writers are total nerds who have never balled a fist in their life, save for a brief shining moment of rage when their wife's bf didn't actually buy them a Steam Deck like he promised. As a result, it's pretty much an untapped niche. Just remember the golden rule of show not tell while incorporating all this and you'll do just fine.

The context was more specifically about the arrival of logic through illogic, a progression that Nietzsche likes pointing at in order to distinguish two conflicting forces: the search for truth and older life-serving errors. He isn't wrong for saying that logic and math would have never come about if thinkers were strictly attempting to draw conclusions from the "real world". Ironically the defenders of logic only put themselves further from the truth: which in this case is that they take themselves without even a grain of salt, and certainly no levity. last_replies.com:
>>21298588
>Soccer bad, tennis good, basketball & hockey middling, American football bad

This is reasonable, except for overrating basketball. (I would call it "football" rather than "soccer" but let's set that issue aside for now.)

What makes a sport beautiful? Some suggestions:


— It should develop ALL the body, rather than just one or more parts of it.

Football (soccer) is imperfect because it over-emphasizes the lower body. If some latter-day Frankenstein were to create the perfect footballer in a laboratory, the result would be like a Tyrannosaurus Rex — huge powerful legs and tiny vestigial arms. (That's probably what we'll have in another fifty years, thanks to genetic engineering.)

Basketball is even uglier than football, for the same basic reason. In basketball, being freakishly tall is a big advantage. To be the best at basketball you have to be too tall for anything else.

This issue also downgrades sports with marked chirality. Most would agree symmetry is aesthetically preferable; an athlete should be reasonably ambidextrous. A sport which uses the right arm exclusively can't be ideal. (You end up looking like that meme of the coomer, haha.) That's a bit of a strike against tennis.


— It should promote overall fitness and health.

The sport should require a good balance between explosive, short-term strength & long-term endurance. Weightlifting goes too far in one direction; marathon running too far in the other.

Also it should not (barring rare accidents) damage the participants. This is the big problem with martial arts, which otherwise seem just about ideal. (It's also why I don't like ballet — it damages the dancers.)


— If a team sport, it should not depend disproportionately on a few individuals.

This is difficult to organize because a star player can always make a big difference. But something like doubles tennis, where both team members are in action all the time, is clearly superior to e.g. cricket, where you might have just one monster bowler or batsman.


— It should end on a climax.

Tennis always ends with someone winning a match-point. A race ends with someone crossing the finishing-line. Those are climaxes. Football just ends when the time runs out; nothing might be happening. Clearly inferior. Basically, any sport that depends on a fixed time is inferior.


VERDICT:

No idea. I watch gymnastics and figure-skating in the Olympics. I prefer tennis to football, mainly because tennis players and tennis fans seem to be a bit more civilized than football players and football fans.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
When you are under the demands of life as a professional, you have to produce something to survive. I would focus on writing as a craft, setting deadlines and progressing through an outline as if it were a job, because it is once you start doing it for a living. These writers you compare yourself to have bills to pay as well.

Put yourself in that position, as if writing is your daily job, because that is what it becomes if you are pursuing the craft for a living.

Even if it has to be a second job, if you set deadlines and plan out your work then make time to get it done, then you can steadily produce books and other material successfully.

After many years of doing this, it is like second nature. Writing is an art form, but it is also a craft that requires a good deal of hard work to make a living writing what people will pay for.

>>21311387
>imagine conflating your shitty severian wankfest with loltia, LOL
i will, because even if for the sake of argument botns is to be a shitty novel, it's still stupid to say 'people dont like the book, but that they can reflect and theorize about it' as if that's not part of the book itself, and true of literature as a whole, beyond 'unreliable narrations' even. reading paradise lost and identifying the themes implicit but not explicitly written does not mean you're suddenly writing your own paradise lost beyond milton's scope. whatever canvas is there, good or bad, wolfe is responsible for it, despite the 'death of the author'

>wolfe's language isn't archaic or undeciphrable
which is point. but it *is* undecipherable for people like the reviewer who have misinterpreted the book and think the lexicon is just old words whose meaning you find in a dictionary. In Wolfe's words:
>I might easily have saved myself a great deal of labor by having recourse to invented terms; in no case have I done so. Thus in many instances I have been forced to replace yet undiscovered concepts by their closest twentieth-century equivalents. Such words as peltast, androgyn, and exultant are substitutions of this kind, and are intended to be suggestive rather than definitive
Again, words are often meant to be evocative. It's a fundamental misunderstanding of the book to think you can 'solve it' by knowing their sources.
One example above: "fuligin", originating from 'fūlīgo' which refers to soot. Yet inferring "carbon colored" is a misstep, fuligin is not 'carbon colored', but described in the book as "being darker than black". These words, just like the world, may mean something to us, but they mean something else to the characters in the setting. Words may vary in obscurity, but since they're all stand-ins for something else, it's really in the context where these are defined. If the book described a cat and called it a dog you'd be a fool saying you easily knew what a dog is. The end result is the language is self-contained, but in-context simple rather than archaic, exactly the sort of thing he was aiming for

>the night land and clark ashton smiths zothique are far better and use far more obscure and rare words
I love CAS, he's a wonderful writer, very prolific in many subgenres and prose and verse both. Also very different from Wolfe, who's not actually about purple prose. (comparisons to Lovecraft I understand, CAS has a lot more imagination, better vocabulary and it never feels tackled on) On themes they're even further away, one influenced by the decadents and later weird fiction, and the other with a strong catholic upbringing and drawing from borges and nabokov, thus the tone of their works is completely different

Would be better if criticisms were not just compromised of wrong readings of his work coupled with namecalling and nothing more. There's no weight in people faulting it for something it's not, rather than its actual faults.

threads.com:
It's that time of the year again. Here are the proposed rules of this year:
- The choices should fall into the literary arena: book of fiction, book of poetry, or book of literary essays. Philosophy, science, politics, and other unfortunate non-fiction genres are not allowed and will be invalidated.
- You can choose up to 5 books but only one book per author. This is done to avoid overrepresentation (e.g. 3 Dostoyevsky novels in the top 25).
- Shakespeare's plays will count towards one book, The Complete Works (how they were originally published). Borges's collections (e.g. Ficciones, The Aleph, Labyrinths, etc) will count towards Collected Fictions (Borges' English releases were kind of botched and irregular). This also done to avoid atomization.
- The titles should be presented in English if they have been translated (e.g. The Divine Comedy rather than La divina commedia). This makes the vote counting easier because the titles are normalized and there's little variation.
- The responses should be in the form "[Book title] by [Author]" rather than "[Author]'s [Book title]"

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
>The methodical task of writing distracts me from the present state of men. The certitude that everything has been written negates us or turns us into phantoms. I know of districts in which the young men prostrate themselves before books and kiss their pages in a barbarous manner, but they do not know how to decipher a single letter. Epidemics, heretical conflicts, peregrinations which inevitably degenerate into banditry, have decimated the population. I believe I have mentioned suicides, more and more frequent with the years. Perhaps my old age and fearfulness deceive me, but I suspect that the human species — the unique species — is about to be extinguished, but the Library will endure: illuminated, solitary, infinite, perfectly motionless, equipped with precious volumes, useless, incorruptible, secret.
I have just written the word “infinite”.' I have not interpolated this adjective out of rhetorical habit; I say that it is not illogical to think that the world is infinite. Those who judge it to be limited postulate that in remote places the corridors and stairways and hexagons can conceivably come to an end — which is absurd. Those who imagine it to be without limit forget that the possible number of books does have such a limit. I venture to suggest this solution to the ancient problem: The Library is unlimited and cyclical. If an eternal traveler were to cross it in any direction, after centuries he would see that the same volumes were repeated in the same disorder (which, thus repeated, would be an order: the Order). My solitude is gladdened by this elegant hope.
Borges seems to be saying that writing is infinite in some way, with its altering and endlessly kaleidoscopic of bounty of meaning.

How yet resolves the governor of the town?
This is the latest parle we will admit,
Therefore to our best mercy give yourselves,
Or like to men proud of destruction
Defy us to our worst; for as I am a soldier,
A name that in my thoughts becomes me best,
If I begin the batt'ry once again,
I will not leave the half-achieved Harfleur
Till in her ashes she lie burièd.
The gates of mercy shall be all shut up,
And the fleshed soldier, rough and hard of heart,
In liberty of bloody hand shall range
With conscience wide as hell, mowing like grass
Your fresh fair virgins and your flow'ring infants.
What is it then to me if impious war,
Arrayed in flames like to the prince of fiends,
Do with his smirched complexion all fell feats
Enlinked to waste and desolation?
What is't to me, when you yourselves are cause,
If your pure maidens fall into the hand
Of hot and forcing violation?
What rein can hold licentious wickedness
When down the hill he holds his fierce career?
We may as bootless spend our vain command
Upon th'enragèd soldiers in their spoil
As send precepts to the leviathan
To come ashore. Therefore, you men of Harfleur,
Take pity of your town and of your people
Whiles yet my soldiers are in my command,
Whiles yet the cool and temperate wind of grace
O'er-blows the filthy and contagious clouds
Of headly murder, spoil, and villainy.
If not, why in a moment look to see
The blind and bloody soldier with foul hand
Defile the locks of your shrill-shrieking daughters,
Your fathers taken by the silver beards
And their most reverend heads dashed to the walls,
Your naked infants spitted upon pikes
Whiles the mad mothers with their howls confused
Do break the clouds, as did the wives of Jewry
At Herod's bloody-hunting slaughtermen.
What say you? Will you yield and this avoid,
Or, guilty in defense, be thus destroyed?

— William Shakespeare, 'Henry V'

I've been trying to think about this for a while now but I'd like to get some opinions. But what really is the quality of timelessness? What makes some books still resonate with us after years, decades and even centuries in some cases? What causes some to be forgotten so abruptly? Why can a silly book about a Toad with poor impulse control still capture my nephews attention so vividly but even things he was super into just get moved on without so much a word?

Maybe I'm just turning into a nostalgic old grump, but I honestly wonder and worry what's it gonna be like in years, decades and possibly centuries down the line from now and what people will think of our generation. And I don't just me the 2020s like the typically zoomber vs boomer argument bullshit. I mean our whole collective generation. What literature really has the power to endure.

>Tolkien wrote that The Story of Kullervo was ‘the germ of my attempt to write legends of my own’, and was ‘a major matter in the legends of the First Age’; his Kullervo was the ancestor of Túrin Turambar, tragic incestuous hero of The Silmarillion. In addition to being a powerful story in its own right, The Story of Kullervo – published here for the first time with the author’s drafts, notes and lecture-essays on its source-work, The Kalevala, is a foundation stone in the structure of Tolkien’s invented world.

Verlyn Flieger, who wrote that above quotation, is the Professor in the Department of English at the University of Maryland.

Why does /lit/ say that the influence of Kalevala was rather minor, when university professors and academia say contrary things and tell us that the Finnish myths and national epics of Finland formed the very backbone of Tolkien's mythological world?

Is the feeling you get when playing vidya just a simulation of times when there is actual opportunity and freedom? There’s nothing else that I get so invested in in my life. I mean I read books and workout and shit, and I encourage others to do so, but there’s nothing else where I can be completely invested in it for 10+ hours without looking up and then wondering where the time flew by. And during that time the vidya is extremely fulfilling.

I suspect this is the same feeling the pioneers settling the continent for instance would’ve felt. Or more descriptively, think of how a legitimately working class guy, who not too long ago was suffering in poverty during the great depression, coming home from ww2 a hero would feel? He’d have a free ride through college, get to marry his hometown sweetheart or someone else most likely (the marriage and fertility rate was off the charts in the late 40s and 50s) and then do whatever he wants with his life with an abundance of jobs that alone could support a cushy suburban lifestyle for him and his nuclear family. Think how fulfilling that would feel and how invested you would be with the irl world. I think that’s the void we’re filling with vidya. We no longer live in a time of great opportunity or real freedom, where the irl world can be something we can get invested in, so instead we have to get our instinctual need for investment and fulfillment through this simulated fashion.

Any books about or related to this?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21309724
The idea is that this phase of philosophy exerts more influence on later and contemporary thought than you would expect. Ours is a world shaped by some of these ideas, it isn't just retreating into something foreign.

As for whether one should demand that people be familiar with medieval philosophy... That I'm not sure I agree with. I took a chance in looking into medieval philosophy and definitely got a lot out of it, but I don't know if it is necessary for everyone.

Check out the Great Chain of Being by Arthur Lovejoy if nothing else. I'm sure there are criticisms of it but it's a good work and is essentially about a thread in the history of thought going from aristotle, through medieval theology, to contemporary scientific concepts. It may be good or bad, but people should know that science now has some heritage in theological ideas. As ridiculous as that sounds (that is why it is important that people should become aware of it).

It's alright, I would recommend you give it a read but can't really recommend the next two books in his Third Reich trilogy. They become increasingly more dry and forgettable, I suppose they would be decent for someone who knows literally nothing about the Third Reich but for me it didn't really broaden or change my perspective in any meaningful way. The Coming of the Third Reich does go into some stuff I never paid attention to before about Weimar Germany, but even then it's like Evans goes out of his way to make everything as bland as possible. Would recommend reading Adam Tooze's The Wages of Destruction or this massive brick brick instead if you want to learn more about the Nazi regime in power. Really extraordinary how this Austrian painter with zero diplomatic training could go toe to toe with every European foreign office on the planet right until the end. I find it's better to go more granular and scholarly when it comes to Nazis because when looking at them in broad strokes from mainstream history books the over-arching narrative about them never changes and you yourself could probably tell half as good as any historian really
